facts.text: Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1944 (Act VI of 1944) was passed in 1944.

Section 4 of the Act provides that every dealer whose gross turnover during the year immediately preceding the commencement of the Act exceeded Rs. 5,000 shall be liable to pay tax on sales effected after the notified date.
Appellant, doing contract work on extensive scale for Central Public Works Department and East Indian Railway, comes within definition of dealer under the Act.
Section 7 requires dealer liable under section 4 to register and possess certificate.
Appellant filed application for registration on 19th December, 1944; certificate issued on 21st December, 1944.

On 8th October, 1945, Sales Tax Officer issued notice to appellant to produce accounts on 10th November, 1945, and show cause why penalty not exceeding one and a half times the tax be imposed under section 10(5).
Appellant appeared before Sales Tax Officer, obtained adjournments till 16th March, 1946, and ultimately failed to appear.
Sales Tax Officer assessed tax at Rs. 4,526-13-0 to best of judgment and imposed penalty of one and a half times under section 10(5).
Appellant appealed to Commissioner; appeal dismissed on 6th June, 1946.
Appellant filed revision petition to Board of Revenue against Commissioner's order; dismissed on 28th May, 1947.

Appellant moved Board of Revenue to refer questions of law to High Court; petition rejected by Mr. N. Baksi on 4th December, 1947, with observation 'No case for review of my predecessors order made out. No reference necessary.'

Under section 21 of the Act, appellant applied to Patna High Court (Agarwala C.J. and Meredith J.) to require Board to state case; High Court directed case back to Board as application misframed as review rather than for stating case, dated 9th September, 1948.
Board reheard, rejected application, refused to state case.
Appellant's second application to High Court rejected summarily.
High Court granted certificate under clause 31 Letters Patent for appeal to Federal Court, influenced by Lahore Full Bench decision.
Appeal filed as Federal Court Appeal No. 71 of 1948, became Civil Appeal No. 61 of 1950.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appeal to the Federal Court (now Supreme Court) under clause 31 of Letters Patent of Patna High Court is maintainable from the High Court's order declining to call upon Board of Revenue to state a case under section 21(3) of Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1944.

petitioner_arguments.text: Resisted preliminary objection relying on Full Bench decision of Lahore High Court in Feroze Shah Kaka Khd v. Income-tax Commissioner.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Clause 31 Letters Patent Patna High Court; Feroze Shah case

respondent_arguments.text: Preliminary objection that appeal is not competent.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sri Mahanth Harihar Gir v. Commissioner of Income-tax; Clause 31 Letters Patent requires final order in original or appellate jurisdiction

court_reasoning.text: High Court order under section 21 is not a final order as it does not of its own force bind or affect rights of parties; it is advisory, with final order by Board of Revenue.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order cannot be regarded as final because it does not bind or affect rights; Board disposes finally.

court_reasoning.text: Order not passed in exercise of original or appellate jurisdiction of High Court; no appeal before it.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Second requirement of clause 31 not satisfied.

court_reasoning.text: View in Patna case (Sri Mahanth Harihar Gir) correct; Lahore Full Bench view not supported, Privy Council refrained from opinion.

holdings.text: Appeal under clause 31 Letters Patent not maintainable from High Court order under section 21 Bihar Sales Tax Act refusing to direct Board to state case, as it is neither final nor in original/appellate jurisdiction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Feroze Shah Kaka Khd v. Income-tax Commissioner, Punjab and N.W.F.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Full Bench held similar appeal maintainable; High Court granted certificate relying on it, but overruled

precedents_cited.case_name: Unnamed Privy Council appeal from above Lahore case
precedents_cited.relevance: Dismissed on merits, refrained from opinion on competency

precedents_cited.case_name: Sri Mahanth Harihar Gir v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar and Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: No appeal lies under cl.31 Letters Patent from order dismissing application under s.66(3) Income-tax Act (similar to s.21 Sales Tax Act)

precedents_cited.case_name: Tata Iron and Steel Company v. Chief Revenue Authority, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court order merely advisory, not final

precedents_cited.case_name: In re Knight and the Tabernacle Permanent Building Society; Ex parte County Council of Kent
precedents_cited.relevance: Jurisdiction consultative, no judgment or order

statutes_cited.name: Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1944
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs liability, registration, penalty assessment, and reference to High Court

statutes_cited.name: Letters Patent of Patna High Court
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for certificate of appeal; requires final order in original/appellate jurisdiction

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Similar provision to s.21 Sales Tax Act

outcome.summary: Preliminary objection upheld; appeal held incompetent and dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "No case for review of my predecessors order made out. No reference necessary."
key_quotes.speaker: Mr. N. Baksi (Board Member)

key_quotes.text: The order appealed against... cannot be regarded as a final order, because it does not of its own force bind or affect the rights of the parties.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The objection is a serious one... their Lordships accordingly refrain from expressing any opinion whatever upon it.
key_quotes.speaker: Privy Council
key_quotes.significance: On competency in Lahore case appeal
